DESCRIPTION: Atomic element, as defined in the periodic table.
Atomic element family (e.g. alkali, noble gas).
Pressure control.
A basis set is a set of functions (called basis functions) which are combined in linear combinations (generally as part of a quantum chemical calculation) to create molecular orbitals.
Type of basis set.

A biomolecule is any molecule that is produced by a living organism, including large macromolecules such as proteins, polysaccharides, lipids, and nucleic acids, as well as small molecules such as primary metabolites, secondary metabolites, and natural products.
Conditions applied to the borders of the box defining the system.
Type of calculation performed during a computational task such as an MD run or a QM calculation.

A carbohydrate is an organic compound comprising only carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen, usually with a hydrogen:oxygen atom ratio of 2:1 (as in water). Carbohydrates are technically hydrates of carbon; structurally it is more accurate to view them as polyhydroxy aldehydes and ketones.
Literature citation
Collision frequency used in Langevin dynamics
Concept related to biomolecular simulations.
Constraint
Algorithm used to define a particular constraint on the system.
Computing environment
Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is a molecule that encodes the genetic instructions used in the development and functioning of all known living organisms and many viruses.
Model used to represent electrostatics (Coulombic) interactions.
Type of ensemble used in a molecular dynamics run (e.g. microcanonical, isobaric-isothermal)
Experiment
Experiment data generating method
Experiment data generating method type
An experiment process is a set of experiment tasks targeting the same molecular system in sequential order (e.g. MD ensemble)
Set of experiments logically associated
Single computational task (as defined in a single input file).
A computer file is a resource for storing information, which is available to a computer program and is usually based on some kind of durable storage.
A file format is a standard way that information is encoded for storage in a computer file.
A file system is a type of data store which can be used to store, retrieve and update a set of files.
A force field refers to the form and parameters of mathematical functions used to describe the potential energy of a system of particles.
Type of force field
Force field parameter set
Functional group in a molecule
Research grant

Lipids constitute a group of naturally occurring molecules that include fats, waxes, sterols, fat-soluble vitamins (such as vitamins A, D, E, and K), monoglycerides, diglycerides, triglycerides, phospholipids, and others.
Specific method for computational chemistry.
Class of methods for computational chemistry.
Family of methods for computational chemistry.
Molecular mechanics integrator
Molecular systems include one or more molecules, with a mixture of solvent and solute.
Group of two or more atoms held together by covalent chemical bonds.
Role of the molecule
Nucleic acids are large biological molecules essential for all known forms of life. They include DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) and RNA (ribonucleic acid).

Protein are large biological molecules consisting of one or more chains of amino acids. Proteins perform a vast array of functions within living organisms, including catalyzing metabolic reactions, replicating DNA, responding to stimuli, and transporting molecules from one location to another.
A residue refers to a monomer within the polymeric chain of a polysaccharide, protein or nucleic acid.
Restraint
Sequence of residues
Ribonucleic acid (RNA) is a ubiquitous family of large biological molecules that perform multiple vital roles in the coding, decoding, regulation, and expression of genes.
Software package used to run a computational task.
Execution events and parameters for a task.
Solvent
Type of solvent model (implicit, explicit, in vacuo)
Spin multiplicity
Temperature control
Time step
Unit shape
